facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 777 of 1962 was filed by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 6, 1962 of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in L.P. Appeal No. 120-D of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 777 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 6, 1962 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in L.P. Appeal No. 120-D of 1960.

facts.text: A number of gold bars, held to be smuggled gold, were recovered from the person of the appellant on September 17, 1957, when he was going in a truck from Jaisalmer to Pokaran.

anchor.surface_text: A number of gold bars, held to be smuggled gold, were recovered from the person of the appellant on September 17, 1957, when he was going in a truck from Jaisalmer to Pokaran. The Superintendent of Land Customs issued a numberice to the appellant on December 4, 1957, to show cause why penal action be number taken against him and as to why the goods should number be companyfiscated under s. 167 8  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878  Act 8 of 1878 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Superintendent of Land Customs issued a notice to the appellant on December 4, 1957, to show cause why penal action be taken against him and why the goods should be confiscated under s. 167(8) of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of Land Customs issued a numberice to the appellant on December 4, 1957, to show cause why penal action be number taken against him and as to why the goods should number be companyfiscated under s. 167 8  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878  Act 8 of 1878 , hereinafter called the Act. The appellant showed cause and on March 21, 1959, the Collector of Central Excise and Land Customs, hereinafter shortly termed Collector, ordered the companyfiscation, of the gold seized from the person of the appellant and imposition of a penalty of Rs. 15,000 on him under S. 167 8  of the Act.

facts.text: Collector of Central Excise and Land Customs ordered confiscation of the gold seized from the appellant and imposed a penalty of Rs. 15,000 on him under S. 167(8) of the Act on March 21, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant showed cause and on March 21, 1959, the Collector of Central Excise and Land Customs, hereinafter shortly termed Collector, ordered the companyfiscation, of the gold seized from the person of the appellant and imposition of a penalty of Rs. 15,000 on him under S. 167 8  of the Act. The appellant presented writ application under art 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Punjab praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Collector dated March 21, 1959 and for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the respondents number to take any steps against him for the realisation of the amount of penalty.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Article 226 of the Constitution in Punjab High Court seeking certiorari to quash Collector's order dated March 21, 1959 and mandamus against respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant presented writ application under art 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Punjab praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the order of the Collector dated March 21, 1959 and for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing the respondents number to take any steps against him for the realisation of the amount of penalty. The writ petition was allowed by the learned Single Judge on the ground that the Collector had number recorded a finding that the appellant was companycerned in the act of smuggling gold into the companyntry, in view of the decision of the Division Bench of the Punjab High Court in Balbir Singh v. Collector of Central Excise Land Customs, New Delhi 1 .

facts.text: Single Judge of Punjab High Court allowed the writ petition on the ground that Collector did not record finding that appellant was concerned in smuggling gold, relying on Balbir Singh case.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was allowed by the learned Single Judge on the ground that the Collector had number recorded a finding that the appellant was companycerned in the act of smuggling gold into the companyntry, in view of the decision of the Division Bench of the Punjab High Court in Balbir Singh v. Collector of Central Excise Land Customs, New Delhi 1 . On letters patent appeal the appellate Bench set aside the order of the learned Single Judge and dismissed the writ petition.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal appellate bench set aside Single Judge order and dismissed writ petition, relying on Union of India v. Jagdish Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On letters patent appeal the appellate Bench set aside the order of the learned Single Judge and dismissed the writ petition. The appellate Bench relied on the Full Bench decision of the Punjab High Court in Union of India v. Jagdish Singh  2 . It was held in that case that it was number necessary for the Collector of Customs to record a formal finding to the effect that the person proceeded against was companycerned in the importing of the smuggled gold.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred this appeal, after obtaining special leave from this Court.

facts.text: Appellant does not question the finding that gold was recovered from his person or that it was smuggled gold.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sharma, for the appellant, does number question the finding that the gold was recovered from the person of the appellant as alleged or that the gold recovered was a smuggled gold.

facts.text: Gold recovered from Shri Radha Kishan while he was taking it to Pokaran in truck No. RJM 40.

anchor.surface_text: In view of all this evidence on record I hold that the gold in question is smuggled one and was recovered from Shri Radha Kishan while he was taking the same to Pokaran in truck No. RJM 40. I therefore order companyfiscation of the seized gold under Section 7 i  of the Land Customs Act I also impose upon Shri Radha Kishan a personal penalty of Rs. 15,000  Rupees Fifteen thousand only  under Section 167 8  of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.

facts.text: It is not disputed that gold cannot be brought into the country without a valid permit.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that gold cannot be brought into the companyntry without a valid permit from the authority empowered to issue it.

facts.text: It is not disputed that the gold recovered from the appellant was imported into the country illegally.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed also that the gold recovered from the appellant was imported into the companyntry illegally.

facts.text: There is no evidence about any action taken by the appellant in connection with the import of the gold found in his possession.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence about any action taken by the appellant in companynection with the import of the gold found in his possession.

facts.text: Appellant's plea that gold was not taken from his person was found to be false by the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be gainsaid that here, apart from the fact that the smuggled gold in a large quantity was found companycealed on the person of Radha Kishan, the plea taken by Radha Kishan that it was number taken from his person was found to be false and this circumstance taken together with the recovery of the smuggled gold would be sufficient for the Collector to be satisfied that Radha Kishan was companycerned in the importation of the smuggled gold.

facts.text: No circumstances alleged connecting appellant with actual importing of the smuggled gold.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case numbersuch circumstances have been alleged which would companynect the appellant with the actual importing of the smuggled gold recovered from his person.

facts.text: No allegation that the appellant himself smuggled the gold from outside the country.

anchor.surface_text: We may also mention here that there is numberallegation that the appellant himself smuggled the gold from outside the companyntry.

facts.text: Punjab High Court appellate bench held that finding that Radha Kishan was concerned in importation was implicit in Collector's order.

issues.text: who can be said to be concerned in any such offence for the purposes of the expression used in the third column relating to penalties under s. 167(8)

anchor.surface_text: The question is, who can be said to be concerned in any such offence for the purposes of the expression used in the third column relating to penalties. Such a person would be one who is concerned in the importation or exportation of such goods whose importation into or exportation from India is contrary to the prohibition or restriction placed under Chapter IV of the Act.

issues.text: whether mere possession of smuggled gold recovered from the person of the appellant justifies the conclusion that the appellant was concerned in the illegal importation of the gold

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the mere finding of fact recorded by the Collector of Customs in this case about the smuggled gold being recovered from the possession of the appellant is not sufficient to conclude, as urged for the respondent, that the appellant was concerned in the illegal importation of the smuggled gold into the country and therefore liable for the penalty under s. 167 8  of the Act.

issues.text: whether it is necessary for the Collector to record a formal finding that the person proceeded against was concerned in the illegal importation before imposing penalty under s. 167(8)

anchor.surface_text: It is true that an omission to record a formal finding to this effect may not be fatal to the imposition of the penalty by the Collector, but the order of the Collector must show that he had considered this aspect of the matter. The order should clearly indicate what matters he had considered to have a bearing on the question of the persons being concerned in illegal importation of the goods

issues.text: whether the findings that gold was recovered from the appellant and was smuggled justify the conclusion that the appellant was concerned in committing the offence of importing gold illegally, and whether the Collector recorded any such finding

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sharma, for the appellant, does not question the finding that the gold was recovered from the person of the appellant as alleged or that the gold recovered was a smuggled gold. His contention is that these findings, by themselves, do not justify the conclusion to the effect that the appellant was concerned in committing the offence of importing gold illegally. His further contention is that the Collector did not record any finding to the effect that the appellant was concerned in such importation of the gold.

issues.text: how the word 'concerned' in s. 167(8) should be construed in light of the policy of the Act and difficulties in proving actual involvement in importation for persons found in possession of smuggled gold

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Prem, for the respondent, has urged that on these facts the appellant must be held to be interested in the importation of the smuggled gold and that the word concerned in s. 167 8  of the Act be construed in the light of the policy of the Act and the difficulties in establishing the fact of a person found in possession of smuggled gold being actually concerned in the importing of it illegally.

arguments.claim: View in Balbir Singh correct that without finding concerned, penalty order invalid

anchor.surface_text: In Balbir Singhs Case there was no dispute that the Collector had not recorded a finding that the petitioner before the High Court was concerned in the offence of importation or exportation of goods which were for the time being prohibited or restricted. It was therefore held that the order imposing a penalty on the person could not be sustained.

arguments.claim: Circumstances in Jagdish Singh different; possession alone not sufficient for concerned in importation

anchor.surface_text: The facts of Jagdish Singhs Case were somewhat different. The conclusion, whose correctness is not before us for decision, about Jagdish Singhs being concerned in the illegal importation of the foreign watches was based not only on his being in possession of those watches after taking delivery of the parcel from the post office but was based on several other circumstances.

arguments.claim: High Courts of Bombay, Calcutta, Madras correctly held mere possession insufficient

anchor.surface_text: The view we have expressed has been taken by the Bombay, Calcutta and Madras High Courts in Pukhraj Jain v. D. R. Kohli Gopal Mayaji v. T. C. Seth Addl. Collector of Customs v. Sitarmn Devi Chand J. Co. v. Collector, Central Excise.

holdings.text: Such a person would be one who is concerned in the importation or exportation of such goods whose importation into or exportation from India is contrary to the prohibition or restriction placed under Chapter IV of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Such a person would be one who is concerned in the importation or exportation of such goods whose importation into or exportation from India is contrary to the prohibition or restriction placed under Chapter IV of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.167(8) linking penalties to offences in column 1 involving prohibited importation under ss.18-19 and Ch.IV.

holdings.text: The interest or the involvement or the engagement or the mixing up of the appellant in the commission of the offence must be at a stage prior to the completion of the offence of illegal importation of gold into the country. Once the gold has been imported, any subsequent interest etc., in the smuggled gold cannot bring in the person showing such interest etc., within the purview of s. 167(8) for the purposes of the imposition of the penalty. The offence of importation of goods is complete when the goods have crossed the customs frontier.

anchor.surface_text: The interest or the involvement or the engagement or the mixing up of the appellant in the commission of the offence must be at a stage prior to the completion of the offence of illegal importation of gold into the country. Once the gold has been imported, any subsequent interest etc., in the smuggled gold cannot bring in the person showing such interest etc., within the purview of s. 167 8  for the purposes of the imposition of the penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines 'concerned' as involvement prior to crossing customs frontier, derived from ss.18-19; post-import possession excluded.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the mere finding of fact recorded by the Collector of Customs in this case about the smuggled gold being recovered from the possession of the appellant is not sufficient to conclude, as urged for the respondent, that the appellant was concerned in the illegal importation of the smuggled gold into the country and therefore liable for the penalty under s. 167(8) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the mere finding of fact recorded by the Collector of Customs in this case about the smuggled gold being recovered from the possession of the appellant is not sufficient to conclude, as urged for the respondent, that the appellant was concerned in the illegal importation of the smuggled gold into the country and therefore liable for the penalty under s. 167 8  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere possession post-importation insufficient without evidence of prior involvement; follows Bombay, Calcutta, Madras HCs.

holdings.text: It is true that an omission to record a formal finding to this effect may not be fatal to the imposition of the penalty by the Collector, but the order of the Collector must show that he had considered this aspect of the matter. The order should clearly indicate what matters he had considered to have a bearing on the question of the persons being concerned in illegal importation of the goods.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that an omission to record a formal finding to this effect may not be fatal to the imposition of the penalty by the Collector, but the order of the Collector must show that he had considered this aspect of the matter. The order should clearly indicate what matters he had considered to have a bearing on the question of the persons being concerned in illegal importation of the goods

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural requirement for reasoned order showing consideration of 'concerned' element, even if not formal; distinguishes Jagdish Singh.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that a mere finding of fact that a person is in possession of smuggled goods does neither imply that the Collector of Customs had considered the question of the persons being concerned in the commission of the offence of illegal importation of the goods nor in any way justifies the conclusion that the person must have been so concerned. Other circumstances indicating that the person had some connection with the importation of the goods prior to their actual import have to be established.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that a mere finding of fact that a person is in possession of smuggled goods does neither imply that the Collector of Customs had considered the question of the persons being concerned in the, commission of the offence of illegal importation of the goods nor in any way justifies the conclusion that the person must have been so concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies rule to facts: possession alone neither shows consideration nor proves concern; no other circumstances here.

holdings.text: In the present case no such circumstances have been alleged which would connect the appellant with the actual importing of the smuggled gold recovered from his person.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case no such circumstances have been alleged which would connect the appellant with the actual importing of the smuggled gold recovered from his person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fact-specific application: absence of pre-import connection evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Such a person would be one who is concerned in the importation or exportation of such goods whose importation into or exportation from India is contrary to the prohibition or restriction placed under Chapter IV of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The interest or the involvement or the engagement or the mixing up of the appellant in the commission of the offence must be at a stage prior to the completion of the offence of illegal importation of gold into the country. Once the gold has been imported, any subsequent interest etc., in the smuggled gold cannot bring in the person showing such interest etc., within the purview of s. 167 8  for the purposes of the imposition of the penalty.

The interest or the involvement or the engagement or the mixing up of the appellant in the commission of the offence must be at a stage prior to the completion of the offence of illegal importation of gold into the country. edges.explanation: Holding mere possession insufficient supports holding mere possession not imply consideration of concern

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the mere finding of fact recorded by the Collector of Customs in this case about the smuggled gold being recovered from the possession of the appellant is not sufficient to conclude, as urged for the respondent, that the appellant was concerned in the illegal importation of the smuggled gold into the country and therefore liable for the penalty under s. 167 8  of the Act.

We are therefore of opinion that the mere finding of fact recorded by the Collector of Customs in this case about the smuggled gold being recovered from the possession of the appellant is not sufficient to conclude, as urged for the respondent, that the appellant was concerned in the illegal importation of the smuggled gold into the country and therefore liable for the penalty under s. 167 8  of the Act.

It is true that an omission to record a formal finding to this effect may not be fatal to the imposition of the penalty by the Collector, but the order of the Collector must show that he had considered this aspect of the matter. The order should clearly indicate what matters he had considered to have a bearing on the question of the persons being concerned in illegal importation of the goods

It is true that an omission to record a formal finding to this effect may not be fatal to the imposition of the penalty by the Collector, but the order of the Collector must show that he had considered this aspect of the matter. The order should clearly indicate what matters he had considered to have a bearing on the question of the persons being concerned in illegal importation of the goods

We therefore hold that a mere finding of fact that a person is in possession of smuggled goods does neither imply that the Collector of Customs had considered the question of the persons being concerned in the, commission of the offence of illegal importation of the goods nor in any way justifies the conclusion that the person must have been so concerned.

We therefore hold that a mere finding of fact that a person is in possession of smuggled goods does neither imply that the Collector of Customs had considered the question of the persons being concerned in the, commission of the offence of illegal importation of the goods nor in any way justifies the conclusion that the person must have been so concerned.
In the present case no such circumstances have been alleged which would connect the appellant with the actual importing of the smuggled gold recovered from his person.
In the present case no such circumstances have been alleged which would connect the appellant with the actual importing of the smuggled gold recovered from his person.
